page.title: 03MORRIS CASTLE, SWANSEA (2)
page.content: The last inhabitant is known to have vacated the premises in 1865. Water, so essential for family life, had to be carried from streams and springs at lower levels. This difficult task led to the gradual vacation of the premises. Stone used for Morris Castle was taken to build nearby cottages. Later, quarrying of underlying sandstone caused the collapse of the south-east and west towers. The end walls of the north-east and west towers still stand. On each floor, a fireplace with its flue is to be seen. Also, there are a number of window openings edged in original brickwork. Apart from being a building of historical interest, the elevated position of Morris Castle gives a breathtaking view of the surrounding area.
